codes.label: Unique alphanumeric identifier assigned to each study
codes.evidence: Not provided in article

codes.label: Last names of the authors as listed
codes.evidence: Knight, L.

codes.label: Year when the publication was published
codes.evidence: Western Kentucky University, Bowling Green, KY August 2021

codes.label: Thesis
codes.evidence: Honors Capstone: A Comparative Analysis of Institutional Trust, Traditional Social Values, and Partisanship in East and Southeast Asia

codes.label: English
codes.evidence: Full text written in English

codes.label: Empirical
codes.evidence: This study utilizes data from the 4th Wave of the Asian Barometer Survey with clearly established data collection via surveys and regression analysis procedures

codes.label: National
codes.evidence: Focus on trust in national government, parliament, and other national institutions in 13 countries

codes.label: Partially
codes.evidence: The study focuses primarily on attitudes toward parliament and other institutions but tests multiple determinants beyond attitudes themselves

codes.label: Stated research question
codes.evidence: For countries in East and Southeast Asia, what influences individual-level trust in government?

codes.label: Stated research question
codes.evidence: Are there certain approaches that more effectively explain levels of individual-level institutional trust?

codes.label: Stated research question
codes.evidence: Are there any broad generalizations that can be made about institutional trust in East and Southeast Asia, or do the explanations about institutional trust vary from country to country?

codes.label: None
codes.evidence: The study does not examine specific behavioral engagement forms such as petitioning, contacting MPs, or voting linked to parliamentary representation

codes.label: Trust/confidence in parliament
codes.evidence: What factors drive an individual to trust, or not trust, their government? The study measures trust in parliament, courts, national government, civil service, military, and police

codes.label: Perceived legitimacy of parliament
codes.evidence: The study examines institutional trust as a measure of legitimacy and includes analysis of partisanship effects on trust

codes.label: Institutional trust definition
codes.evidence: Individual-level institutional trust in government refers to citizens' confidence and evaluations of governmental institutions and their performance

codes.label: Traditional Social Values definition
codes.evidence: This measure reflects 'social values' in daily social settings and positive attitudes toward paternalism, harmony orientation, and collectivism

codes.label: Comparative (two or more cases)
codes.evidence: This study compares 13 countries in East and Southeast Asia: Japan, Hong Kong, South Korea, China, Mongolia, Philippines, Taiwan, Thailand, Indonesia, Singapore, Vietnam, Cambodia, Malaysia, and Myanmar
The surveys constituting the 4th Wave of the ABS were conducted between 2014 and 2016

codes.label: Japan; Hong Kong; South Korea; China; Mongolia; Philippines; Taiwan; Thailand; Indonesia; Singapore; Vietnam; Cambodia; Malaysia; Myanmar
codes.evidence: The regional sample size of 19,467 from 14 different countries and territories in East and Southeast Asia

codes.label: Surveys
codes.evidence: This project utilizes data from the 4th Wave of the Asian Barometer Survey (ABS), which contains survey data

codes.label: Secondary data extraction
codes.evidence: The Asian Barometer Project Office is solely responsible for the data distribution. Analysis conducted using secondary Asian Barometer data

codes.label: Secondary
codes.evidence: Data analyzed in this paper were collected by the Asian Barometer Project. The Asian Barometer Project Office is solely responsible for the data distribution

codes.label: Quantitative (statistical modelling, regression analysis)
codes.evidence: This analysis will first be conducted on the full thirteen-country data set utilizing Trust Index 1 as the dependent variable, creating three models using OLS regression analysis

codes.label: Main finding on traditional social values
codes.evidence: Traditional social values are meaningful determinants of political trust. In every single model included in this paper, evaluations of the national economic situation and governmental anti-corruption efforts have a significant, positive impact on institutional trust

codes.label: Main finding on partisanship
codes.evidence: At the regional level, for each model the winner and loser dummy variables have significant impacts on institutional trust, positive for the case of the winner variable and negative for the loser variable

codes.label: Main finding on social capital
codes.evidence: For both social trust and organizational membership, there is a much greater level of variation in significance from model to model and from country to country, suggesting the institutional approach is more consistent than the cultural approach

codes.label: Coding notes
codes.evidence: This is an honors thesis examining institutional trust determinants across 13 East and Southeast Asian countries using secondary Asian Barometer Survey data with regression analysis methodology
